author: Dominic Robertson
title: Shropshire river levels expected to peak today after Storm Gerrit battering
text: Shropshire river levels expected to peak today after Storm Gerrit battering River levels were expected to peak in the county today and into tomorrow after a battering from Storm Gerrit. Flood defences were put up in Shrewsbury and Ironbridge earlier this week as the Environment Agency prepared for the impact of the swollen River Severn. A flood warning issued for Shrewsbury on Thursday afternoon said that flooding of property, roads and farmland is "expected" and that the river is likely to peak at the Welsh Bridge on Friday evening. A [flood warning was issued for The Quarry and The Showground](https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/environment/flooding/2023/12/28/flood-warning-issued-for-shrewsbury-after-day-of-heavy-rain-across-shropshire/) in the county town on Thursday evening after a day of heavy rain. Levels in Crew Green and Shrewsbury were predicted to hit their peaks of 6m to 6.3m and 3.2m to 3.6m respectively today, with the water expected to work its way down the Severn to peak at 4.8m to 5.3m in Ironbridge and 4m to 4.4m Bridgnorth later today, and into tomorrow. It comes after the county was hit by [extremely strong winds and rain from Storm Gerrit](https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/environment/2023/12/28/flood-alerts-for-shropshire-as-storm-gerrit-continues-to-batter-the-uk/) early yesterday morning. The storm uprooted trees and also appears to have been responsible for a [huge 'bang', heard in Bridgnorth](https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/local-hubs/bridgnorth/2023/12/28/lightning-strike-like-an-explosion-rocks-bridgnorth-/) – with residents describing the noise as like an "explosion". The boom was heard around 10.50pm on Wednesday, and was accompanied by a bolt of lightning. Caroline King who lives in Low Town explained how it had even destroyed her internet connection. She said: "There was a massive lightning bolt through my windows and then a massive bang. My WiFi router has blown from it. It is still out now and I won't be back online until next Wednesday, which affects me as I work from home. My power hasn't been affected but I believe it has been for a lot of residents in Low Town." Meanwhile the Environment Agency has urged people to take caution around the rising rivers amid the festive celebrations. Chris Bainger, the Environment Agency Fisheries Technical Specialist for Shropshire, Herefordshire, Worcestershire and Gloucestershire, posted an update on social media saying: "A reminder please, with the festive period coming please stay away from swollen rivers and standing water, it is not a safe place to be." A motorist also had to be freed by fire crews after their vehicle [got stuck in water](https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/local-hubs/telford/2023/12/28/vehicle-freed-from-water/) during heavy rain near Telford. The incident at around 1.30pm yesterday near the former Grove Inn pub in Walcot saw a fire crew from Wellington attend. A spokesman for the Shropshire Fire and Rescue Service said the vehicle was hauled free from the water using the fire engine. Meanwhile flood warnings were still in place for Melverley and Maesbrook, with less severe flood alerts for the Rea Brook and Cound Brook, the Dee catchment from Whitchurch to Chester, the River Lugg north of Leominster, the Severn throughout Shropshire, and the Severn/Vyrnwy confluence and Tern and Perry Catchments. More rain is also forecast for this weekend. The Met Office says 2023 will end on an unsettled note with [strong winds and rain returning](https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/environment/2023/12/28/rinse-and-repeat-weather-experts-warn-of-another-soaking-on-the-way-at-the-weekend/) to the UK. During the early hours of Saturday they say a potentially deep area of low pressure will move in from the west to affect Ireland and western parts of the UK. At the moment it doesn't look like snow will be a feature in the Midlands though. But they say a band of "transient snow" could be a feature further north.

author: Mal Taime
title: Hagen residents' plea for betelnut control - Post Courier
text:
“There must be a complete ban on betel nuts within the vicinity of Mt Hagen City because it is tainting a bad picture to the general public.”
Wilson Moke, a local from Mt Hagen, said this as the city of Mt Hagen is riddled with betelnut stains, tarnishing the image of the city.
Mr Moke said chewing and spitting of betelnut stains everywhere in the town looks unhygienic because it was spoiling the image of the town.
He supported the call made by Western Highlands Provincial Member Wai Rapa recently encouraging the people to do away with betelnut trading and do something else because it was not supporting the Small Medium Entrepreneurs (SME).
Mr Moke said the call by the Western Highlands Provincial Member Wai Rapa was a welcoming one because betelnut was not grown in the Highlands, thus it created a lot of stains and mouth cancer, but the Highlands people trade betelnut as one of their daily business activities.
Read more in your nambawan daily Post Courier tomorrow – Thursday, July 03, 2025.

author: Vatican News
title: Gallagher en Croacia: Seamos constructores de paz
text:
Gallagher en Croacia: Seamos constructores de paz
Vatican News
En el marco de su visita de tres días a Croacia, el secretario vaticano para las Relaciones con los Estados y las Organizaciones Internacionales, monseñor Paul Richard Gallagher, presidió la tarde del 31 de mayo, una celebración eucarística en Zagreb con motivo de la fiesta de Nuestra Señora de la Puerta de Piedra, patrona de la capital croata.
En su homilía, hizo un llamamiento a ser capaces de ver la obra de Dios incluso en medio de las muchas dificultades y «destrucciones» de hoy, como pudieron hacer la Virgen María y su prima Isabel, que creyeron y esperaron antes de ver el cumplimiento de las promesas de Dios.
El arzobispo Gallagher recordó que la imagen de Nuestra Señora de la Puerta de Piedra que emergió intacta de entre las ruinas de esa puerta, la entrada oriental de la antigua ciudad, tras un incendio, fue fuente de asombro y esperanza para sus «angustiados y desconcertados» habitantes. «Hoy en el mundo no faltan escenas de trágica destrucción», dijo el arzobispo, causadas por fenómenos naturales, pero también «por esa insensatez humana a la que el Papa Francisco se refiere desde hace tiempo como la “tercera guerra mundial a trozos” que se está convirtiendo en un “verdadero conflicto global”». Por eso es importante volver a mirar esa imagen.
En el centro de la liturgia de hoy está el encuentro entre María e Isabel, ambas inesperadamente futuras madres. Una maternidad que trastorna sus planes, subrayó Monseñor Gallagher, pero que es acogida con alegría. Su pensamiento se dirige a las madres de hoy: «Que Nuestra Señora de la Puerta de Piedra -dijo- acompañe a todas aquellas mujeres que reciben en su seno la semilla de una nueva vida, incluso cuando llega de forma inesperada» y saben verla como «un don de Dios». Esto no siempre ocurre en nuestras sociedades, señaló el Secretario para las Relaciones con los Estados, pero para los creyentes, la vida debe ser siempre promovida y defendida.
Lectio magistralis
También el 31 de mayo Secretario para las Relaciones con los Estados y las Organizaciones Internacionales impartió una Lectio magistralis celebrada en la Universidad Católica de Croacia. El tema fue La persona humana: una comunión de relaciones.
“Hay una cuestión que es bien conocida por cada uno de nosotros pero que, al mismo tiempo, es cada vez más incomprendida en el mundo actual. Esta cuestión se refiere a la realidad de la persona humana, es decir, nos afecta a cada uno de nosotros como seres sociales, en relación unos con otros. A pesar de que estamos innatamente conectados entre nosotros, tenemos la tentación de aislarnos, de excluir al otro y a todo lo que es diferente de nosotros”, este escenario fue subrayado enfáticamente por el Arzobispo Paul Richard Gallagher.
“Aunque la relación interpersonal pueda parecer un concepto abstracto, está en el centro de todas las interacciones sociales”. En particular, el arzobispo Gallagher analizó el efecto que tiene nuestra comprensión del zoon politikon en nuestro enfoque de la sociedad y nuestro sentido de la identidad. “Desgraciadamente, en el mundo actual existe la tendencia a convertir el «sano patriotismo en peligroso nacionalismo»: esto se debe en gran medida a nuestra comprensión inherente de la persona humana”.
Hoy en día, en las interacciones sociales -señaló el prelado- existe una fuerte tendencia a recurrir al individuo como punto de referencia. Así, la sociedad se concibe como formada por individuos autónomos que interactúan entre sí en una especie de atomismo social. Sin embargo, este enfoque directo de la sociedad es relativamente nuevo. En la concepción tradicional de la sociedad, la atención no se centra en el «yo» del individuo, sino en el «nosotros» de la persona humana.
Gracias por haber leído este artículo. Si desea mantenerse actualizado, suscríbase al boletín
[ pulsando aquí](/es/inscripcion-boletin-de-noticias.html)

author: World News
title: Christmas Eve worshippers to face security screening at Cologne cathedral
text: Cologne police acting on indications of a possible attack searched Germany’s landmark cathedral with sniffer dogs on Saturday and said worshippers attending Christmas Eve Mass would undergo security screening before being allowed in. In Austria, police in Vienna also said they were taking heightened security measures around churches and Christmas markets, deploying both uniformed and plainclothes officers. Neither police agency specified the threat, but the German news agency dpa said authorities were responding to signs of a possible attack by Islamic extremists, without citing a specific source. Cologne’s towering cathedral, whose twin spires are 157 metres (515 feet) tall, is a major tourist destination visited by some six million people a year. Police and cathedral officials urged those attending Mass on Sunday evening to arrive early and not bring bags or purses. The European Union’s home affairs commissioner, Ylva Johansson, warned on December 5 that Europe faces a “huge risk of terrorist attacks” over the Christmas holidays due to fall-out from the war between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas.
